q1.question:
This city’s neighborhood of Tepito is a center for the veneration of “Saint Death.” The Ten
Tragic Days ended with Francisco Madero's [MUH-dare-oze] assassination in this city. Two
sprinters made a salute to "Black Power" at the 1968 Summer Olympics held in this city. This
city was built over the ruins of an older city on Lake Texcoco by the Spaniards. For 10 points,
name this city that serves as the capital of a country south of the Rio Grande.

In the Treaty of Petropolis, this country acquired territory from its neighbor that would
become the rubber-tree-rich State of Acre. Its capital was designed by Lucio Costa[LOOSE-eeoh KAH-stah] and Oscar Niemeyer [NEE-uh-my-ur] in the shape of an airplane. The Piraha
people are found in this country’s largest state, whose capital Manaus [muh-NOUSE] is on the
banks of the Rio Negro [NEH-GROW] and the Amazon. For 10 points, name this Portuguesespeaking South American country, the fifth-largest country in the world.

This ruler's successor was given the Shahnama [SHAH-nuh-mah] of Shah Tahmasp [TAHmosp]. This ruler, who allied with Francis I and sponsored Piri Reis [PEER-ee RAY-iss], was the
first ruler served by the Grand Vizier Mehmed Sokullu Pasha [soh-KOOL-uh POSH-uh] and was
married to Hurrem Sultan [HOOR-em SOOL-tahn]. This ruler besieged Esztergom [EZZ-turrgohm] and defeated Louis II at the Battle of Mohacs [MOH-hotch] to conquer Hungary. This
ruler, who was nicknamed for his law-giving abilities, seized Baghdad. For 10 points, name this
sultan who presided over the peak of the Ottoman Empire.

This region’s Qajar [kah-JAR] Dynasty was founded by a eunuch. Another of its rulers
invaded India and carried away the Peacock Throne. This nation was led by Nadir. Another
leader of this nation signed a deal with the company that would become BP to develop this
region’s oil fields. That ruler belonged to the Pahlavi [pah-lah-vee] Dynasty. For 10 points, name
this country that, before the Islamic Revolution, was ruled by the Shah.

tossup.question:
In this war, the French captured Minorca [min-OR-cuh], which was returned at its end.
Saltykov [SALT-yuh-koff] and Loudon [loo-dohn] dealt a heavy loss to the Prussians at
Kunersdorf [KOON-urs-dorf] in this war in which Rossbach [ROSS-bock] and Leuthen [LOYtunn] were sites of victories by Frederick the Great. Canada became a British colony after the
Treaty of Paris that ended this war. For 10 points, name this worldwide war that lasted from
1756 to 1763.

bonus.question:
A theater of the Seven Years’ War called the Third Carnatic War took place in which
modern-day country?

tossup.question:
The sancai [san-tsye] technique of three-color pottery glazing dates to this dynasty. Yang
Guifei [yong gwee-fay], one of the Four Beauties, was the consort of this dynasty’s Emperor
Xuanzong. It was interrupted by the Second Zhou [zhoe] Dynasty of Empress Wu, and it rose to
power after the Sui [sway] dynasty. Its first emperor was Taizong, and Li Po and Dufu were
famous poets who lived during this dynasty. For 10 points, name this Chinese dynasty that lasted
from 618 to 907.

bonus.question:
The Tang [tong] dynasty faced this rebellion, led by a namesake general, who
established the Yan dynasty.

q3.prompt: During the Crusades, who or what…

questions.question: Led Muslim resistance to the Third Crusade after capturing Jerusalem in 1187?
Led the Third Crusade as the King of England and won the Battle of Arsuf [ar-soof]?
Was a military monastic order founded in 1119 and named after a prominent Jerusalem site?
answer: Poor Fellow-Soldiers of Christ and of the Temple of Solomon
Soldiers of the Temple of Solomon

questions.question:
Was the other prominent Christian military order, which survived on Malta and Rhodes after
the Crusades?
answer: Order of the Knights of St. John

questions.question: Was the city, notably not in the Holy Land, was the capital of an Empire led by Alexius I?

Was the 1187 crushing defeat for the Kingdom of Jerusalem that prompted the launch of the
Third Crusade?
questions.answer: Battle of the Horns of Hattin

questions.question: Was the first ruler to use the title “King of Jerusalem”?
Was the last Crusader city to fall, in 1291?

q3.prompt: In the year 1956, who or what…

questions.question: Was re-elected President of the United States?
Lost the US Presidential election?
Was the European country invaded by the Soviet Union in October to put down a revolt?
Was the country that joined France and Britain in briefly seizing control of the Suez Canal?
Was the New York Yankees pitcher who threw a perfect game in the World Series?
Was the nation led by Anastasio Somoza Garcia, who was assassinated in 1956?
Was the nation that hosted the first Summer Olympics in the Southern Hemisphere?
The Italian ocean liner that sank off the coast of Massachusetts, killing 46 people?
The Spanish administrative capital, still the capital of modern Cuba?
Song inspired by Jose Marti [mar-TEE] that became the most famous patriotic song of Cuba?

The main crop of Cuba, whose workers were organized into a revolution by Carlos Cespedes
[SESS-pay-dace] and which is used to make rum?
The knife-like weapons with a Spanish name used by revolutionaries under Carlos Cespedes?

The manifesto written by Pierre Soule [soo-LAY] that declared that the U.S. should acquire
Cuba?
The war begun by Carlos Cespedes, named after a period of time?
answer: la Guerra de los Diez Anos

questions.question: The Spanish general nicknamed “the Butcher” for his brutality?
The U.S. ship sending weapons to Cuba that was seized, leading to a namesake affair?

Which was home to the Etemenanki Ziggurat [EE-tem-un-ONN-kee ZIGG-ur-ot] as well as
according to legend the Hanging Gardens?

Which was the last capital of the Shang [shong] Dynasty and the site of a number of Shang
royal tombs?
Whose walls crumbled under attack by Joshua?
The site of a namesake “lighthouse” as well as the Sarapeum [suh-ROPP-ee-um]?
Whose ruins are on a peak overlooking Peru’s Urubamba [ooh-roo-BAHM-buh] Valley?
That gave its name to the country once called Rhodesia [roh-DEE-zhuh]?
Which was a Nabatean [nah-buh-TAY-uhn] capital located in present day Jordan?

Where Monks Mound was built? Once of the largest cities in the Americas, it is currently next
to St. Louis.
The title of the de facto military rulers of feudal Japan?
The military class banned from carrying swords and then abolished during modernization?
The emperor who launched a namesake period of modernization?
The other Asian power which Japan defeated in an 1894-5 war?
The peninsular country annexed by Japan in 1910, ending its Choson Dynasty?
The crushing naval victory by Japan over Russia in 1905?
The port gained on the Liaodong peninsula by Japan after the Russo-Japanese War?
The treaty ending the Russo-Japanese War signed in a New Hampshire city?

Overthrew the Lodi Dynasty, which was based in which city whose “new” version is the
capital of modern India?
Created which tomb for the wife of Shah Jahan?
Was founded by which Turko-Mongol leader who won the First Battle of Panipat [pah-neepot]?
Was ruled by which “Great” Emperor who founded the religion Din-e-Ilahi [din-ee-ill-ahhee]?

Fought against which Maratha king, a master of guerrilla warfare who won the Battle of
Pratapgarh [prah-top-gad]?

Was led in the 17th century by which man, who defeated his brother Dara Shikoh at the Battle
of Samugarh [sahm-oo-gad]?
Was temporarily overthrown by which Pashtun warlord who oversaw many civil reforms?
Ended after the deposition of this final Emperor in 1857?
answer: Mirza Abu Zafar Sirajuddin Muhammad Bahadur Shah Zafar

q3.prompt: In the Peloponnesian War, who or what was the...

questions.question: Century in which the conflict took place?
Author of a contemporary history of the war?
City whose namesake decree issued by Athens started the war?
Leader of Athens in the first part of the war who gave a famous funeral oration?
Island that was the target of a disastrous Athenian expedition led by Nicias [nih-see-us]?
Group of slaves in Sparta incited by Athens to revolt?

Leader of Sparta who won the battle of Aegospotami [ee-go-spot-uh-mee], the decisive battle
of the war?
Group of people that took power in Athens after the end of the war with the help of Sparta?

parts:
(30 pts) The first meeting of this political party ended with "three cheers for the Queen Empress." One prime minister from this party died in Tashkent the day after reaching a
peace agreement with a neighboring country. That leader's successor, also from this party,
declared a (20 pts)

state of emergency in 1975, after which this party lost an election to Morarji
[more-are-jee] Desai's Janata Party. Three generations of politicians from this party have
been (10 pts)

prime minister, beginning with Jawaharlal [juh-wah-har-lull] Nehru. For 10 points,
name this political party that led the Indian independence movement.

(30 pts) This product was blended with more palatable herbs in order to create madak [mahdokk]. The two principal areas of modern creation of this product are called the Golden
Crescent and the Golden Triangle. This product names a conflict during which the (20 pts)

Taku forts were destroyed that was sparked by the boarding of the H. M. S. Arrow. A letter
to Queen Victoria asking why this commodity was legal in her country was written by (10 pts)

Lin Zexu, who angered British merchants by destroying large amounts of it. For 10 points,
identify this narcotic drug whose trade sparked two wars between China and Britain.

(30 pts) Ancient gods worshiped by this ethnic group included Uzza [ooz-ah] and Hubal. It
fought the Byzantine Empire at the Battle of Yarmouk. This ethnic group’s rebellion was
subdued in the Wars of Apostasy, after which their invasions brought down the (20 pts)
Sassanid [sass-uh-nihd] Empire. This ethnic group loyally followed the Rashidun [rash-eedone] after being subdued by (10 pts)

Abu Bakr [ah-boo bah-kur], and originally pledged loyalty to
a prophet who took dictation from Gabriel in a cave. For 10 points, name this largely Islamic
ethnic group that populates a peninsula northeast of Africa.

(30 pts) Regina Ip resigned from the government of Tung Chee-hwa in this city after 2003’s 1
July March. That march was in protest of Article 23 of this city’s (20 pts)

Basic Law. The “right
of abode” in this city was expanded by its Court of Final Appeal in 1999. This city was the
site of (10 pts)

2014 protests aimed at the ouster of Chief Executive CY Leung that were termed the
“Umbrella Revolution.” The United Kingdom returned this city to its present country in 1997
after a 99-year lease. For 10 points, name this city, a Special Administrative Region of China.

(30 pts) The state of Cundinamarca [koon-deen-uh-mark-uh] was set up in this modern-day
country, whose capital was recaptured at the end of the “Foolish Fatherland” period.
Periods of unrest in this country have included the War of the Thousand Days and the mid20th-century struggle called “La (20 pts)

Violencia.” This country lost western territory when
Philippe Jean Bunau-Varilla helped orchestrate a 1903 revolution against it that promoted (10 pts)

canal-building interests. For 10 points, identify this country from which Panama gained
independence.
